name: Tartu
fun_fact: Fun fact: Estonian black rye bread (must leib) is so culturally sacred that when someone moves into a new home, Estonians bring bread and salt to a 'soolaleivapidu' (salted bread party). If you accidentally drop bread, you must kiss it as a sign of respect. There's even a marriage proposal saying: 'Paneme leivad Ã¼hte kappi' - 'we should keep our bread in the same cabinet.'

hero_dishes.name: Must Leib (Estonian Black Rye Bread)
hero_dishes.description: Dark rye bread that is an essential component of any traditional Estonian meal, made from rye cultivated in Estonia for over a thousand years
hero_dishes.origin_story: During the Middle Ages, Estonia was known across Europe as a major rye exporter. The Sangaste winter rye variety, created in 1875 at Sangaste Manor in South Estonia, is the oldest cultivated rye variety in the world. Rye has been central to Estonian agriculture for over a millennium.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Look for 'Tartumaine Toit' label in Tartu stores (indicates local production). Best enjoyed with soups, alongside main courses, with Baltic herring on top, or with salted butter. Available at all local bakeries and restaurants.

hero_dishes.name: Mulgipuder
hero_dishes.description: Rustic porridge of mashed barley and potatoes, often with bacon and sautÃ©ed onions, served with sour cream and rye bread
hero_dishes.origin_story: The ONLY Estonian national food on the UNESCO List of Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity. Traditionally associated with Southern Estonia, now enjoyed throughout the country as a typical home-cooked meal and common restaurant dish.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: PÃ¼ssirohukelder (modern twist - serves it alongside French fries in a bun), Peasantry Museum Restaurant (inside Estonian National Museum, traditional Estonian meals in modern way with historic setting), traditional restaurants in Tartu

hero_dishes.name: Verivorst (Blood Sausage)
hero_dishes.description: Blood sausage made from pork, pig's blood, onions, barley, allspice, and marjoram, stuffed into pig's intestine - Estonia's national dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional winter meal, usually served during Christmas festivities when piles are roasted together with potatoes and pork. The name literally means 'blood sausage.' Considered THE national dish of Estonia.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Served with lingonberry jam, butter, sauerkraut, or sour cream. Available at traditional Estonian restaurants, especially during winter and Christmas season. Restaurant Antonius (historic building blending old Estonian tastes with modern cooking)

hero_dishes.name: Kama
hero_dishes.description: Finely milled mixture of roasted barley, rye, oat, and pea flours - unique Estonian food product served as breakfast or snack
hero_dishes.origin_story: Not baked as bread, kama is mixed with sour milk or kefir as a quick meal. Its bittersweet taste also complements fresh fruit, coffee, and cocoa powder. Traditional Estonian breakfast staple.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Krempel cafÃ© (beloved by locals for freshly baked goods and traditional breakfast), local cafÃ©s throughout Tartu

signature_drinks.name: Kali (Kvass)
signature_drinks.description: Estonia's national drink - low-alcohol, sour-sweet, fizzy beverage made from fermented rye bread, cross between beer and soda, also known as kvass or gira
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Dating back to medieval times, still popular among Estonians today. Made at home using birch sap, bread, berries, fruits, and dried ingredients. Commonly found at street food markets and festivals. Considered non-alcoholic but may have up to 1% alcohol after fermentation.

signature_drinks.name: Vana Tallinn
signature_drinks.description: National drink of Estonia - sweet and strong spiced liqueur with hints of cinnamon and vanilla
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served as a digestif or mixed in cocktails. The iconic Estonian spirit known worldwide.

signature_drinks.name: Kasemahl (Birch Sap Beverage)
signature_drinks.description: Traditional drink made from birch sap, whose popularity peaked in the 20th century
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Seasonal drink harvested in spring when sap flows. Some Estonians still consume it as a traditional beverage.

food_culture_notes: Tartu County is Estonia's annual culinary region, showcasing distinctive food cultures
'Tartumaine Toit' label in stores indicates products made or produced in Tartu County
Rye bread cultural practices: kissing dropped bread, 'soolaleivapidu' (salted bread party) for new homes, bread and marriage proposals
Traditional Estonian cuisine based on meat and potatoes, fish in coastal areas, now influenced by international foods
Peasantry Museum Restaurant inside Estonian National Museum offers history-focused dining
Restaurant Antonius occupies a historic building blending old Estonian tastes with modern cooking
